title: FDA says new test finds "unacceptable levels" of...
text:
Federal health officials say they have found 'unacceptable levels' of a cancer-causing chemical in several heartburn medications, including Zantac.

On Wednesday, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) said limited testing showed the drug contained unsafe levels of N-nitrosodimethylamine (NDMA).

Previously, the FDA said its preliminary tests found that levels of NDMA 'barely exceeds amounts you might expect to find in common foods.'

In past studies conducted on animals, NDMA has been linked to several cancers including colorectal, kidney, liver and stomach.

The news comes on the heels of Walmart, the largest retailer in the US, announcing that it was pulling Zantac and other over-the-counter ranitidine medications from its shelves.

On Wednesday, the FDA announced it found 'unsafe levels' of NDMA, which is classified as a probable human carcinogen, in heartburn drugs such as Zantac. Pictured: A box of Maximum Strength Zantac tablets at a pharmacy in Miami Beach, Florida

The FDA did say its low-heat testing method found much lower levels of NDMA than a higher temperature method used by a third-party laboratory.

NDMA was formerly used in the production of liquid rocket fuel and additives for lubricants, according to the Environmental Protection Agency.

However, after several lab tests, it was classified as probable human carcinogen.

Zantac is the fourth leading antacid tablet and, as of 2018, was worth an estimated $128.9million.

Several pharmacy chains have announced that they are suspending sales of Zantac due to the troubling findings.

This includes CVS Health Corp, Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc and Rite Aid Corp, most of whom say the drug can be returned the store for a refund.

Many grocery stores are still selling the drug, but Kroger recently announced it won't be, according to USA TODAY.

However, the drug's maker Sanofi - headquartered in Paris, France - said it will continue to ship Zantac to the US.

For heartburn sufferers, health experts recommend using alternatives such as Nexium or Prilosec, or their generic versions, all of which retail around the same price.

This is not the first that NDMA has been found in common medications.

Last year, the FDA began investigating whether NDMA and other impurities were in blood pressure and heart failure medicines called Angiotensin II Receptor Blockers.

Several recalls were issued and the FDA advised that anyone taking the drugs should continue to do so because the risk of cancer was much lower than risks of suddenly stopping the drug.

The agency is still investigating this issue and, last month, it sanctioned a manufacturing plant in India that makes some of the ingredients used in ARBs.

US and European health regulators said last month they were reviewing the safety of ranitidine, while Canada requested makers of the drug to halt distribution as it gathers more information.

The FDA on Wednesday asked ranitidine makers to conduct their own laboratory testing to assess levels of the impurity and to send samples of their products for testing by the agency.
